comments.content: You can configure a mixed wireless network mode with WPA2 Enterprise on channel 11. Mixed supports older and newer standards.

WPA2 (Wi-Fi Protected Access 2) Enterprise requires more robust security mechanisms and features that are not supported by the older 802.11b standard. Therefore you can't choose MIXED and WPA2 Enterprise, you must choose 802.11g which supports the necessary encryption and authentication mechanisms to implement WPA2-Enterprise securely.
you can use 1,6, or 11.
non-overlapping channel. 1,6,11... See Net+
Why change to 11

802.11g and b which I assume is what they're getting to here - doesn't support WPA2. Only WPA, WEP and Radius.

comments.content: You do not know how wifi channeling works. The best options are 1 6 11 as those have no overlap between each other. Using any other channel with 1 6 11 or their neighbors will cause overlap.

discussion.content:
Basic Wireless Settings:
Wireless Network Mode:
G Only 
-Higher through put capability
-5.0 ghz
-This is the option with the most security

Wireless Network Name(SSID): Default
On the exam, if we have the option to change this, I would lean towards changing it because it would make it more secure to change it from default.

Wireless Channel: 9
Based on the information given, 9 is going to be the option least used. 1-6 would be default and most people would gravitate to 1-6.

Wireless SSID Broadcast: Disable
Because that way you're less likely to have someone insert a rogue access point

Security Mode: WPA2 Enterprise
It connects back to the RADIUS server. This helps verify that you are who you say you are. Someone would have to have your credential information in order to log onto that wifi
https://www.linksys.com/support-article?articleNum=137534#:~:text=If%20you%20have%20multiple%20devices,specific%20wireless%20standard%20as%20well.

discussion.content:
Let me share my humble opinion...
With this "Network Diagram" all servers and WiFi controller are in different networks and not able to reach each other. So the only setup left is :
Wireless Network Mode - Mixed (No security implications and no information to decide)
Wireless Network Name (SSID) - DEFAULT
Wireless Channel - Any channel is proper (No security impact -probability for ch.11to be free is higher ) 
SSID Broadcast - disable (gives false security feeling but reduces number of people that will try to connect by mistake.)
Security Mode - WPA2 PSK (Higher security mode available with this infrastructure setup)

Please correct me if I am wrong!

comments.content: WPA2 PSK should never be used in that type of environment.
WPA2 Enterprise as it connects to a radius server.

discussion.content:
ssh-keygen -t rsa: Generates a new RSA key pair, creating both a private key (id_rsa) and a public key (id_rsa.pub).
ssh-copy-id -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub user@server: Copies the public key to the authorized_keys file on the remote server, enabling passwordless login for that user.
ssh -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa user@server: Tests passwordless authentication by attempting to connect to the server using the private key. If successful, authentication will proceed without prompting for a password.

ssh-copy-id -i ~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub user@server

discussion.content:
Changed my mind the SSH Key authentication commands is mentioned in the book.

------------------From ChatGPT ---------------
Setting up passwordless SSH authentication using SSH keys involves a few steps. Here are the commands to achieve this:

Generate SSH Key Pair on Your Local Machine:

>> ssh-keygen -t rsa

This command generates an SSH key pair (public and private keys) by default in the ~/.ssh/ directory.

the Public Key to the Remote Server:

>> ssh-copy-id username@remote_server

Replace "username" with your remote server username and "remote_server" with the server's address. This command will copy your public key to the server and set up passwordless access.

Test the Passwordless SSH Access:

>> ssh username@remote_server

You should now be able to access the remote server without being prompted for a password.

Selected Answer: A
They did a good job at providing other options for a possible answer, but it is definitely 'A,' Single-Sign On. They want to use their own company credentials, and they want to have less info the employees have to remember or know, therefore, it's an enterprise setting which means Kerberos as their SSO option. Meaning no other option would suffice.

Selected Answer: A
A. SSO (Single Sign-On).

Single Sign-On (SSO) enables users to authenticate once with their domain credentials and then access multiple applications and services without needing to enter their credentials again. By integrating SaaS applications with SSO, employees can use their existing domain credentials to seamlessly access these applications, improving convenience and reducing the burden of managing multiple sets of credentials.

questions.question_text: A data administrator is configuring authentication for a SaaS application and would like to reduce the number of credentials employees need to maintain. The company prefers to use domain credentials to access new SaaS applications. Which of the following methods would allow this functionality?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Containers are well-suited for constantly changing environments because they provide a consistent and isolated environment for applications to run, regardless of the underlying infrastructure. They are highly portable and can be quickly deployed, making them a flexible solution for dynamic environments where applications need to be scaled, updated, or moved frequently. Real-time operating systems (RTOS) are designed for predictable and deterministic tasks, while embedded systems and SCADA are more specialized and may not be as adaptable to rapidly changing conditions.

Selected Answer: B
It's containers

Selected Answer: B
B Is correct

questions.question_text: Which of the following would be best suited for constantly changing environments?
A newly identified network access vulnerability has been found in the OS of legacy IoT devices. Which of the following would best mitigate this vulnerability quickly?

comments.content: A legacy device refers to an older model that is no longer actively supported with software updates
I agree with you also replacement isn't a quick solution due procurement process installing, configuring, and patching etc..

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
Patching doesn't work as it's legacy, Segregation is the quickest option of the remaining three.

Selected Answer: C
If support from the manufacturer is not available, and the vulnerability is in the OS of legacy IoT devices, the best option to quickly mitigate the vulnerability is C. Segmentation.

Since patching may not be feasible without manufacturer support, segmentation can help isolate the vulnerable devices from the rest of the network. This can limit the potential attack surface and reduce the risk of exploitation, even if the devices themselves cannot be patched or updated. Segmentation can be an effective short-term strategy to enhance security when dealing with unsupported legacy IoT devices.If support from the manufacturer is not available, and the vulnerability is in the OS of legacy IoT devices, the best option to quickly mitigate the vulnerability is C. Segmentation.

Since patching may not be feasible without manufacturer support, segmentation can help isolate the vulnerable devices from the rest of the network. This can limit the potential attack surface and reduce the risk of exploitation, even if the devices themselves cannot be patched or updated.

comments.content: Please remember that legacy generally mean that it is either end of life or no support is provided any longer. Naturally, there is no patch for such devices, otherwise, they are not legacy.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
Patch management can also be difficult for legacy systems, proprietary systems, and systems from vendors without robust security management plans, such as some types of Internet of Things devices. These systems will need compensating controls(ex.Segmentation ), or some other form of risk mitigation if patches are not readily available.
Patching is the most effective and efficient way to mitigate a vulnerability in legacy IoT devices quickly.

comments.content: Do not confuse the meaning of the word mitigate to be fix. If you have a leak in your roof, you can mitigate the leak by using a tarp over the area. The leak has not been fixed, but it has been mitigated to prevent further damage to the structure.
The question is also giving you a hint by stating "legacy IoT devices"..generally means, no patches/support or updates available.

discussion.content:
The question is asking to mitigate ...quickly - patching better than segmentation.
segmentation would not fix a vulnerability - would isolate it...but not fix.
The question was asking to mitigate.

Selected Answer: B
Patching is not Updates , legacy devices may not get OS updates but can get hot-fixes or patches. And Anyway those IoT devices should be on segmented network anyway.
That how I see it but maybe I'm wrong.

Selected Answer: C
I am sure it’s SEGMENTATION

Selected Answer: C
tell me how youre gonna patch legacy....

Segmentation can be used to isolate the legacy IoT devices from the rest of the network. However, segmentation does not mitigate the vulnerability. It simply prevents the vulnerability from being exploited by attackers who have already gained access to the network. B
